RESIDENT
              & FELLOW
              SECTION
                              Clinical Reasoning:
Section Editor                Rapidly progressive quadriparesis in a
Mitchell S.V. Elkind,
MD, MS                        forgetful patient

Laura Mantoan Ritter,         SECTION 1
                                                                                                                    Figure          MRI brain (fluid-attenuated inversion
   MD, PhD, MRCP              A 50-year-old right-handed retired family business                                                    recovery sequence) shows high signal in
Jeremy D. Isaacs, PhD,        manager developed progressive left-sided weakness over                                                the corticospinal tract (small arrows)
   MRCP                       5 days after a mechanical fall. She remembered catching
Meriel McEntagart, MD         her foot on the carpet and falling down a flight of stairs,
John P. O’Dwyer, MA,          followed by severe neck pain over C4-C5 and inability
   MD, MRCPI                  to get up for nearly an hour. Over the subsequent
                              month her symptoms progressed and she presented to
                              the hospital with an asymmetric spastic paraparesis, loss
Correspondence to             of pinprick sensation in her arms and legs, loss of vibra-
Dr. Mantoan Ritter:
lauramantoan@doctors.org.uk
                              tion sense to both hips, and double incontinence.
                                  MRI of the patient’s cervical spine revealed severe
                              cervical canal stenosis but no cord abnormality, while
                              brain MRI showed high signal in the corticospinal tract
                              bilaterally (figure). Somatosensory evoked potentials
                              (SSEPs) were of low amplitude but not delayed. The
                              patient stabilized on a rehabilitation ward and was dis-
                              charged home independent and continent but with
                              some frequency of micturition.
                                  When reviewed in clinic 2 months later, the patient
                              had significantly deteriorated, was wheelchair-bound,                              Although not formally measured, there was relevant sulcal
                              and complained of memory deterioration, slurred speech,                            enlargement, including a wide sylvian fissure (thick arrow) and
                              coughing on free fluids, and new right-sided weakness.                             widening of the right central sulcus at the lateral aspect
                                                                                                                 (sequence not shown), suggestive of frontotemporal atrophy.
                                  The patient’s medical history included unex-
                              plained collapses with a postictal confusional period                              housework and was unable to reason in a 2-step strat-
                              of 30 minutes since age 14 years. Her mother died of                               egy (such as making decisions about her own care). She
                              dementia at age 68 and her brother of a stroke at age                              was concrete in her ways and did not want any change.
                              50. She was an ex-smoker of 20 cigarettes per day and                              She had dysarthria with mild nasal escape and a spastic
                              rarely consumed alcohol.                                                           quadriparesis with pyramidal weakness (worse on the
                                  On cognitive assessment using the Addenbrooke’s                                left and in her upper limbs), sustained ankle clonus,
                              Cognitive Assessment–Revised, the patient scored 67/                               and hyperreflexia. Sensory examination was normal.
                              100, losing points for attention; poor category and
                                                                                                                 Questions for consideration:
                              letter fluency; memory, naming, and abstract reason-
                              ing; writing; and constructional ability. She also had                             1. What is the differential diagnosis in a patient with
                              behavioral changes: she was disinhibited and emotion-                                 pyramidal weakness and cognitive problems?
                              ally labile (pseudobulbar affect with pathologic smiling                           2. In view of her imaging results and abnormal SSEP,
                              and laughter). She had become disorganized with                                       what tests should one consider?




                                                                                                                                                                 GO TO SECTION 2

                                SECTION 2                                                              cytoplasmic antibodies, immunoglobulins, and serum
                               In a patient with chronic progressive motor symptoms                   protein electrophoresis, were normal or negative.
                               and cognitive problems, the differential diagnosis                         CSF analysis revealed a normal cell count, normal
                               includes inflammatory, infectious (e.g., HIV, Lyme                     cellularity, and no growth after 48 hours incubation,
                               disease, Whipple disease, neurosyphilis, and non-                      ruling out an active inflammatory process. CSF glu-
                               tuberculous mycobacterial infection), metabolic/toxic,                 cose and the CSF glucose/serum glucose ratio were
                               neurodegenerative, and paraneoplastic causes (table).                  normal. Oligoclonal bands were negative and CSF
                               An initial screen should include a full blood count with               protein was marginally elevated at 0.71 g/L.
                               differential, urea and electrolytes (including corrected                   A paraneoplastic syndrome was also considered.
                               calcium and phosphate concentrations), liver function                  CT of thorax, abdomen, and pelvis only showed a
                               tests, amylase, and C-reactive protein, which were nor-                few calcified nodules within both hemithoraces, consis-
                               mal in our patient. Normal thyroid function tests and                  tent with previous granulomatous infection. Bilateral
                               vitamin B12 levels ruled out hypothyroidism and B12                    mammograms were unremarkable. In view of the rapid
                               deficiency as a metabolic cause of her symptoms.                       progression of the patient’s symptoms, an MRI of her
                               She had a slightly low folate level of 3.0 mg/L (normal                brain was repeated with gadolinium administration,
                               range 5–10 mg/L). Ferritin, lead, cadmium, and                         showing once again the high signal in the corticospinal
                               thallium levels were measured to exclude toxic                         tracts and asymmetrical bilateral frontotemporal atro-
                               causes of encephalopathy and motor symptoms                            phy (figure). She declined a body PET-CT.
                               and were normal. Serologic investigations for                              In view of the patient’s previous history suggesting
                               inflammatory diseases, including serum angiotensin-                    seizures and to ensure her cognitive problems were not
                               converting enzyme, rheumatoid factor, antineutrophil                   due to underlying ictal phenomena, an EEG was




Table       Differential diagnosis for progressive pyramidal weakness and cognitive problems

Differential diagnosis                     Clinical characteristics                                        Diagnostic tests

Neurodegenerative diseases

  Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)      Combination of upper and lower motor neuron signs               EMG shows denervation. NCS show normal motor and
  with frontotemporal dementia             (fasciculations) plus frontotemporal cognitive deficits         sensory conduction (no conduction block). MRI: high
                                                                                                           signal in corticospinal tracts and frontotemporal atrophy
                                                                                                           (but mainly used to rule out other causes). SSEPs: loss of
                                                                                                           or low amplitude. Neuropsychology suggestive of
                                                                                                           frontotemporal deficits.

  Alzheimer disease (AD) with              Autosomal dominantly inherited syndrome of AD-type              Neuropsychometric testing shows focal or lateralized
  presenilin-1 (PSEN1) mutation            dementia; onset in early 50s is typical; associated with        cognitive deficits with early involvement of memory and
                                           heterogeneous neurologic symptoms including spastic             learning. CT/MRI: generalized or focal atrophy. PET/
                                           paraparesis (which is a strong indicator for PSEN1              SPECT: hypoperfusion/low metabolism in hippocampus,
                                           mutation), seizures, and myoclonus                              precuneus, and parietotemporal cortex (AD). Genetic
                                                                                                           testing for PSEN1 mutation.

  Corticobasal degeneration (CBD),         Insidious onset, cortical dysfunction with sensory              Neuropsychometric testing shows focal or lateralized
  progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP)     disturbance (alien hand) and apraxia, extrapyramidal            cognitive deficits with sparing (CBD) of memory and
                                           dysfunction (akinetic-rigid syndrome)                           learning. CT/MRI: focal/asymmetric atrophy (CBD),
                                                                                                           midbrain atrophy (PSP). PET/SPECT: focal/asymmetric
                                                                                                           hypoperfusion with sparing of basal ganglia (CBD).

  Wilson disease (with neurologic          Psychiatric symptoms, dementia, rigidity, and                   Serum: ceruloplasmin level below 20 mg/dL. Urine: urinary
  involvement)                             extrapyramidal features; Kayser-Fleischer corneal arcus         copper excretion .100 mg over 24 hours. MRI: high T2
                                           in 50%–60% of patients; family history                          signal in basal ganglia, brainstem, white matter. Genetics:
                                                                                                           mutation in Wilson gene ATP7B on chromosome 13.

  Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease                Rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, ataxia,                MRI: high signal in putamen and head of caudate
                                           pyramidal signs                                                 (sensitivity 83%–92%, specificity 87%–95%). CSF:
                                                                                                           positive for protein 14-3-3 (can be normal in familial
                                                                                                           forms and elevated in nonprion disease of the CNS).
                                                                                                           EEG: periodic synchronous biphasic or triphasic sharp
                                                                                                           wave complexes (sensitivity 67%, specificity 85%).

Inflammatory/autoimmune disease

  Inflammation (acute disseminated         Gradual/subacute onset of sensory and motor deficit;            MRI: high T2 and FLAIR signal, new lesions enhance with
  encephalomyelitis, MS)                   cerebellar, brainstem signs or myelopathy                       contrast. CSF: positive for unmatched oligoclonal bands in
                                                                                                           MS (pleocytosis or increased protein common in ADEM).
                                                                                                           Visual- and brainstem-evoked responses can be delayed.

Paraneoplastic disease

  Paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis 6       Subacute encephalitis with confusion, behavioral and            Serum: positive anti-Ro, La, Hu, Ma2, GAD/amphiphysin,
  anterior horn cell involvement           cognitive difficulties, brainstem signs                         or TPO antibodies, CT thorax/abdo/pelvis, PET scan,
                                                                                                           mammogram, testicular ultrasound to identify possible
                                                                                                           primary tumor.

                                                                                                                                                         Continued


                                                                                                     Neurology 81    November 19, 2013                            e155

   Table        Continued

  Differential diagnosis                     Clinical characteristics                                      Diagnostic tests

  Nutritional/metabolic deficiencies

    Vitamin B12 deficiency                   Subacute combined degeneration of the cord, dementia,         Serum: B12 levels low.
                                             encephalopathy, sensory polyneuropathy

    Folate deficiency                        Subacute combined degeneration of the cord-like               Serum: folate levels low.
                                             picture

    Hypothyroidism                           Cognitive slowing and dementia, fatigue, constipation,        Serum: TSH high or low, fT4 and fT3 low.
                                             cold intolerance

    Adult-onset metachromatic                Autosomal recessive, presents with dementia or                Serum: deficiency of arylsulfatase A.
    leukodystrophy                           psychiatric features, pyramidal signs, speech problems,
                                             ataxia

    Adult-onset hexosaminidase A             Autosomal recessive, variable clinical features even          Assay of hexosaminidase A enzymatic activity; if
    deficiency                               within same family, can present with spinal muscular          decreased: molecular genetic testing for HEXA mutations.
                                             atrophy or early-onset ALS features (wasting, weakness,
                                             fasciculations, upper motor neuron signs), dysarthria,
                                             and cognitive impairment

    Adult polyglucosan body disease          Autosomal recessive, progressive upper and lower motor        MRI: progressive white matter changes (paraventricular,
                                             neuron signs with gait difficulty, mild cognitive             subcortical, and as far as the craniocervical junction).
                                             impairment, neurogenic bladder dysfunction                    NCS/EMG: lumbosacral axonal polyradiculoneuropathy.
                                                                                                           Sural nerve biopsy: typical polyglucosans within nerve
                                                                                                           tubes. Low glycogen branching enzyme (GBE) activity in
                                                                                                           skin fibroblast cultures and GBE1 mutations on
                                                                                                           molecular genetic testing.

  Infectious causes

    HIV                                      AIDS dementia complex in advanced disease;                    Serum: HIV serology, CD4 count, viral titer, check for
                                             myelopathy due to IRIS or JC virus infection                  concomitant hepatitis coinfection.

    Syphilis                                 Delirium and dementia; myelopathy and sensory                 Serum: VDRL/TPHA test.
                                             neuropathy

    Chronic Lyme disease                     Lyme encephalopathy or (rarely) chronic                       Serum/CSF: high titer of anti–Borrelia burgdorferi IgM or
                                             encephalomyelitis with spastic paraparesis, cranial           IgG (ELISA followed by a Western blot) or isolation of B
                                             neuropathies, and cognitive impairment; arthritis;            burgdorferi from clinical specimen.
                                             acrodermatitis chronica atrophicans

    Whipple disease                          Migratory arthralgia, diarrhea, abdominal pain; cognitive     Demonstration of Tropheryma whippelii on small-bowel
                                             dysfunction, oculomasticatory myorhythmia, gaze palsy;        biopsy (periodic acid-Schiff–positive macrophages). MRI/
                                             multiple neurologic symptoms possible                         CT may show high signal lesions in CNS disease. PCR of
                                                                                                           CSF, brain tissue, and peripheral blood possible.

  Toxic causes

    Heavy metal poisoning (lead, mercury,    Acute confusion, dementia                                     Serum: lead and mercury levels.
    cadmium, thallium)

Abbreviations: ADEM 5 acute disseminated encephalomyelitis; FLAIR 5 fluid-attenuated inversion recovery; GAD 5 glutamic acid decarboxylase; Ig 5
immunoglobulin; IRIS 5 immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome; MS 5 multiple sclerosis; NCS 5 nerve conduction studies; SSEP 5 somatosensory
evoked potential; TPHA 5 Treponema pallidum hemagglutination assay; TPO 5 thyroid peroxidase; TSH 5 thyroid-stimulating hormone; VDRL 5 Venereal
Disease Research Laboratory.



                                 performed. This showed diffuse theta waves, suggestive               vital capacity of 0.9 L. Early morning arterial blood
                                 of a mild nonspecific cerebral dysfunction. EMG                      gas analysis showed a pO2 of 9.73 kPa and a pCO2
                                 showed evidence of widespread chronic partial dener-                 of 9.84 kPa, with a base excess of 3.4 mmol/L.
                                 vation with active changes in all 4 limbs and respiratory
                                 muscles. In view of the rapidly progressive course of the
                                                                                                      Questions for consideration:
                                 illness, the abnormalities were interpreted in keeping
                                 with a diagnosis of motor neuron disease, possibly with              1. What is your diagnosis?
                                 associated frontotemporal dementia.                                  2. How would you interpret the MRI findings?
                                     By then, the patient had developed prominent fas-                3. What further tests could you consider to investi-
                                 ciculations in upper and lower limbs and had a forced                   gate the cause of her disease?

                  DISCUSSION ALS is familial in 5%–10% of cases.                  No targeted funding reported.
                  Up to 50% of patients with ALS also develop cogni-
                  tive impairment, while 5%–15% are diagnosed with                DISCLOSURE
